module.p: a-steach [to] inside is an illative adverb of motion along a trajectory (contrasting with both the inessive a-staigh [at] inside and the elative a-mach [to] outside).

section.p:
Some examples –
a-steach do into –
older pedagogical examples –
Tha mo mhàthair a’ sgrìobhadh litreach gu m’athair a tha air falbh. Thubhairt mo mhàthair, “An téid thu do bhocsa nan litrichean leis an litir seo, Iain?” “Théid,” ars Iain, “falbhaidh mi an dràsda”. “Fuirich gus an dùin mi i is gus an cuir mi seòladh oirre. Ceannaich fhéin stamp agus cuir oirre i.” Tha Iain a’ ruith sìos an rathad leis an litir ’na làimh. Théid e a steach do oifig a’ phuist, ceannaichidh e stamp is cuiridh e sud air an litir. [...]
My mother is writing a letter to my father who is away. My mother said, “Will you go to the postbox with this letter, John?” “Yes, I will,” said John, “I will leave now.” “Wait until I seal it and put an address on it. Buy a stamp and put it on it.” John is running down the road with the letter in his hand. He will go into the post office, he will buy a stamp and put that on the letter. [...] td. 5
a-steach can serve as complement to certain verbs.

module.p:
rach a-steach – go inside, enter –
pedagogical examples –
Chaidh e a-steach don togalach às an robh an t-seinn a’ tighinn.
He entered the building from which the singing was coming. td. 49

thig a-steach – come inside, enter –
pedagogical examples –
Tha Anna a’ tighinn a-steach. | Thàinig iad a-steach. Thig(ibh) a-steach.
Ann is coming in. | They came in. Come in. td. 31, 196
Nach tig thu a-steach?
Won’t you come in? td. 578

Note the dialectal alternative thig a-staigh –
pedagogical examples –
Thig a-staigh. Tha e fuar an-diugh. | Tha i a-muigh an sin a’ bruidhinn ach cha tàinig i a-staigh fhathast. | Is e Seumas a thàinig a-staigh. | Chì thu amannan nan trèanaichean air a’ bhòrd-shanais ach cluinnidh tu caismeachd mus tig an trèan a-staigh dhan an stèisean.
Come in. It’s cold today. | She is out there talking but she hasn’t come in yet. | It is James that came in. | You will see the train times on the notice board but you will hear an announcement before the train comes into the station. td. 34, 50, 134
